author: Niamhh1
title: brilliant nurses
body:
I was in this morning at 8.30am, I have been coming to the Mandeville now for about 4 or 5 weeks.  
The nurses are absolutely A1. They are all brilliant.  
The food is lovely, the vegetable soup is very nice.  
I have absolutely no complaints at all.  
Cleanliness is great.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
title: The care in Lurgan is brilliant
body:
I was previously in Craigavon hospital, the care in Lurgan is brilliant. The staff have a lot of time for you and are very attentive to everyone.  
I know it’s hard to keep everyone happy as the nurses are rushed off their feet as it is, but they are doing a wonderful job.  
The food is grand, I do eat most of the meals. I have drank about 100 cups of tea I would say since I’ve been in.  
I can feel a massive improvement on my mobility, due to the physio sessions.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
title: The menu variety isn’t great
body:
My care in Lurgan is perfect. All of the staff are lovely and are always very empathetic.  
My appetite isn’t great, the food is not bad though, but I am often not able to eat a lot. The menu variety isn’t great, lunch and dinner menus are far too similar.  
Communication is very good, the nurses are never misleading and are always open nears to listen to any of my concerns.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
title: Everything is good
body:
The care I have received in Lurgan has been first class.  
The staff are great- I couldn’t say a bad word about them.  
The food is absolutely lovely, I am enjoying it very much.  
Cleanliness is great, my room is lovely and tidy.  
I haven’t got any complaints at all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
title: happy enough in lurgan
body:
I came to Lurgan hospital from the Royal, the ambulance brought me over.  
I wasn’t waiting too long for an ambulance, it was grand.  
The food is alright, just sort of the same stuff all the time. Not a lot of choice. There’s only really a few things I like on the menu so it’s just sort of a rotation of them meals.  
The ward is very clean, top class cleaners.  
I am happy enough in Lurgan, very content because I am well looked after by the wonderful staff.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Community Midwife
title: GP out of hours service
body: I am a midwife and phoned the GP out of hours service at Knockbreda about a client I was concerned about. Both the person I spoke to on the phone and the out of hours GP were excellent, listened and understood my concerns and provided very timely provision of care. I was impressed by the thoroughness, care and attention of the GP not only in their contact with my client but also in following up with me afterwards. Thank you.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Niamhh1
title: So thankful for all their help
body:
The staff are honestly just the best, I am so thankful for all their help. They are an absolutely great team!  
The care is fantastic. It can often get boring in the hospital sitting around all day, looking at 4 walls, however I call with my children every night, just on my own mobile but I think the virtual visiting service is a great way for people to communicate with their families. Especially if they are not able to visit and don’t live close by, it’s very handy.  
The food has been lovely, I try to eat as much of it as I can, but I’m not really a big eater. The only thing I would change would be the length of my stay😂.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
title: Not much too complain about- good care!
body:
The staff on Ward 1 are lovely, great great nurses.  
The food is okay, it fills a hole.  
It is a great hospital and everyone is very friendly. The cleaners are great, the ward is very clean. I would maybe say if anything needs improved it would be the food, however everything is alright.  
I haven’t much to complain about, I am getting fantastic care.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ingridnt
title: Royal Sussex Brighton - Level 11 Gynae
body:
My mother was admitted to the ward where she sadly passed away from terminal illness. Myself and my brothers can’t praise the staff of Ward 11 highly enough for the care and kindness they showed our Mum the entire time.  
The treatment, care, compassion and support Mum and our family received was outstanding and we are so grateful that what has been a desperately sad time was made easier by the wonderful team on the ward.

author: Fifi74
title: Chest infection
body:
Felt chest infection start on Christmas day but I knew the GP was closed so waited a few days to call. Asked for triage and was offered face to face appointment. This surprised me but I took the appointment as I knew the GP would need to see me and it saves a triage appointment.  
The GP was not my usual GP but she was lovely, kind, friendly. Explained all treatment options and what to do if it worsens.

author: Goldfinch7
title: Support from Talk together Bromley
body:
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']  
[Very happy with 'Staff skills']  
[Very happy with 'Being listened to']  
[Very happy with 'Seeing the whole me']  
[Very happy with 'Involved in decisions']

author: Sarah2023
title: Thank you for your kindness when my nana died
body:
I would like to say a huge thank you to the staff working on C31 in December on a night shift (I’m afraid I didn’t catch names). My nana was admitted to this ward where sadly she rapidly declined and passed away in the early hours of the morning.  
One of the nurses on the ward had kindly spoken to me in a very calm manner (via telephone), in particular when I couldn’t process what was happening.As I was travelling from Scotland and unable to make it to her before her passing, the staff on the ward had kindly allowed her body to remain in a resting environment where both me and my sister were able to spend time saying our goodbyes to her. The auxiliary/ care assistant had kindly made me a cup of tea too and checked to make sure that both me and my sister were okay.  
I was also able to speak to the doctor that morning with no questions asked where he was able to explain the diagnosis in more detail. And again, thank you for taking your time to do that as I know you had to be called in to speak to me specifically.  
Thank you ward C31.

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: If only all Care homes were as good as this one
body:
Could not have wished for better. The carers were brilliant and talked and laughed with us when appropriate, Foocaring and supportive. Food excellent, fresh ingredients, may I add very capable chefs.
Glad to get home now but still miss Dovecote Lodge.

title: Dreadful experience
body:
Called 111 initially, and was told need to see doctor with 2 hrs, none available.
Then Waited more then 4 hours in A&E to be called to go urgent GP for another 2 hrs wait 
There is no indoor waiting area for non patient

title: Staff Going the Extra Mile
body:
I would like to pass on my thanks to all the staff who managed the A&E department in Cheltenham on the afternoon and evening of 27th December 2022. The department was the busiest that I had ever seen, with the waiting room full and many people queuing down the corridor outside Radiology, others were sitting on the floor or were standing. Waiting time was 5-hours. Regardless of these pressures the reception, nursing, and Doctor team were exceptional and maintained their composure, and professionally moved us through the system. We were warned that A&E would close at 10pm (we arrived at 5.20pm) and therefore potential that we may not be seen that evening. Instead, staff from wards were reassigned to manage the A&E and we were eventually seen at 3.30am. We left at around 4am where a small handful of people remained to be seen in the waiting room. 
I do believe that a town the size of Cheltenham is worthy of an overnight A&E department, so I am grateful to your teams who went the extra mile to bridge this gap on 27th December.

title: Telephone consultation
body: Excellent service.  Doctor took the time to listen to my views. Only negative comment would be that the call was 35 minutes later than the appointment time.

title: Great practice
body: Prompt answering of call. Friendly receptionist. Timely contact from on-call doctor and prescribed medication which was available for same day collection. Many thanks

title: Cannot fault the care given
body: In the week between Christmas and New Year we fully expected to have a long wait for assessment and treatment of my husband’s acute back pain. However, within three hours we had been seen, treated, reviewed and we’re on our way home. Every single member of staff in the department were caring, sympathetic and helpful. Thank you so much to you all.

title: Terrible Service
body: Appalled, rang at 10.45am on 23/12 as housebound mum who lives a minute away from surgery is showing signs of a UTI which she often has succumbed to in recent weeks. To avoid a hospital visit via ambulance especially at this time, we asked for either antibiotics she has had before or an appointment. Anyone who has an elderley relative knows how this can escalate. Told by the receptionist that we need to either call 111 or the out of hours after 6.30pm as there are no appointments available. How was my mum assessed? By someone who had no medical training whatsoever! We know the signs and as they are now not open till Weds, we have to hope she does not deteriorate. She suffers from a multitude of heart and kidney conditions. No wonder A&E are on their knees, GPs need to not allocate responsibility to assess a patient to someone untrained, something which a few seem to relish. Very upset as a quick assessment now could mean the difference between staying in her own home or attending hospital via ambulance. We would have happily popped round with a sample to test but the untrained individual had a script and stuck to it, no matter the possible consequences.

title: Unhelpful
body: Rang at 8am and after a long hold was told there was no appointments left for my 3 year old that had a chest infection - was told multiple times by the receptionist to just take him to a and e to get him antibiotics. Thought this was quite irresponsible to suggest as these services are already over run and in my opinion should be avoided unless gravely ill.

title: Helpful practice
body: Lovely doctor, very kind and helpful. Gave me lots of advice and helped me to arrange an appointment with a physio therapist in a very short time.

title: Care I  received was second to one
body:
Staff do a brilliant job nurses lookc
Cannot faued after me all day and night cannot thank them and all the other staff including porters

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor service from medication team
body:
I recently had the misfortune of dealing with the medication team when a family member became terminally ill. 
one of them was fantastic but the other 2 definitely need training! 
One of them didn’t have a clue what she was talking about and the other one answers the phone very loudly, chewing down the phone and continues to eat while she talks to you. VERY unprofessional. She then demanded we sent an email request for syringe drive medication …. Patients dying and she’s demanding an email! Both of them didn’t have a clue what most of the medication was, surely the practice would be better employing people who have some medication knowledge. But one thing both of them definitely need is lessons in how to deal with patients instead of being rude! Feel sorry for the third member of this team who must carry the can for the other two

title: Terrible practice
body:
The receptionists are rude and unhelpful, and purposely decline calls or put you on hold for a long time when you are trying to book an appointment. They are always 'overbooked' and it is impossible to get an appointment or even a telephone consultation from a doctor. Anytime they do pick up the phone and you try to book an appointment, they tell you to try the NHS App and hang up, even though there is usually no availability on the app for 'the next 12 weeks'. 

I had an appointment earlier this month and I was turned away by receptionists saying the doctor would be unable to see me, even though I had an appointment with them. This incident was such an inconvenience to my routine on that day, and I was very disappointed with the practice. 

If you are looking to become a patient here, I would not recommend this practice to you. The reception staff are incredibly disorganised and inefficient and it is incredibly hard to be seen by a doctor. I have now left this practice.

title: 7 hours Wait
body: I felt I was in a backward third world country!  People were vomiting, crying obviously distressed yet they were left to fend for themselves sitting on hard chairs with 2 health care workers looking on showing no compassion or care.  People were coming in and being told if you stay you will have to wait 7 hours.  No out of hours GP service anymore, A&E refusing to see people and sending everyone that can walk to this terrible place it felt desperate like a dumping ground

title: Outstanding
body: Phoned 5am 31/12/22 flu / chest infection ..  dr phoned 7.30am .. asessed at wombwell 10.20am prescribed antibiotics… remarkable response… professional understanding dr .. prescribed appropriates antibiotics .. thank you so much

title: Crawley Comit Cancer Ward
body: The nurses on comit ward at Crawley hospital. So friendly and well mannered and can't be more helpful, Right down to the reception staff. Thanks for all you've done for me.

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Outstanding support
body: I was suffering with back pain and an appointment was made to see a Senior Doctor after I reported a particularly painful weekend. The Doctor almost immediately homed in on the issue....but continued to do a thorough assessment.  She arranged for an MIR scan to be considered  on an urgent basis and spoke to the nuerology team at the Hospital... all while I was sitting in her surgery. I went to the hospital...but they sent me home... the Doctor persisted and suggested a private MIR scan and wrote a reference for me at 9 pm to ensure I could get the scan immediately. The results of the scan ,  confirmed her concerns that I had a prolapse disc and I needed some urgent attention. Having got these results back from the MRI scan she again contacted Coventry University  within the hour and arranged for a specialist to assess me and provided a reference from the Surgery.  She rang me at the Hospital at 8 pm to check something was happening. This is an example the Doctor\ Practice going above and beyond my expectations...and I am indebted to her for her help. Thank you

title: Useless Booking System
body: Been contacted by Text and then by Letter to book an appointment with CHEC about my eyes.  All the links they provide are useless and you cant book an appointment. The phone service is also useless and you cant make an appointment.

title: Bad service
body:
I visited WGH on the 27/12/22 A&E department for my child which is 5 years old had fever for last 2 months( prior to that I have taken my child to see 111 out of gp service, A&E doctor and my own gp already) no one has done anything, not any test or anything to find out about the high temperature ) when I visited on the 27/12/22 I have explained to the children A&E doctor everything all the previous visit which I made to see the doctors, the doctor seems not really care, I asked the doctor to take some test and find out why my child keep getting high temperature for last 2 months, she said it’s virus fever  her ear got red no point taking any test and they were planned to give her ear spray and send her home, but my child heart rate was raised high even with out fever , so the doctor went and talked to her boss and he explained that it’s not a good thing to send them home with high heart rate and after that done some blood test, so still that doctor not taken any swab test to see any other virus to find out, around 11 pm informed me they are going to give some antibiotics and check her heart beat and we need to stay at hospital tonight, after that around 12:30 am they started the antibiotics and moved us to the ward at 1:30 am and we settled there, suddenly around 4:15 am the nurse wake me up and said my child heart rate is gone down to normal level and we can go home now, I was shocked how can I go at 4 am? I said I can’t go and I will go in the morning, when it’s morning come my daughter heart start beating faster and high temperature, they were asked me to wait for other 3 hrs to observe her, finally around 10 am we left the hospital but they asked us to come for antibodies on the same day evening 

We gave her antibodies for 2 days but her temperature never gone down she always had temperatures above 39.

So we was worried I told my concern to the nurse which I have to say thanks to her she is the only one listen to me, she talked to the doctor again and the doctor come and talk to me and decided to do more test and asked us to stay in the hospital. 

We stayed there again done some swab test and blood test and X-ray, her. Swap test came positive with the virus which is make her severely ill, she had antibodies after that and got discharged after 2 days. 

When I asked the discharge summery they just gave me just the admission and discharge details. When I requests to get my daughter blood test results details the nurse kept saying doctors only have access and they are busy right now I waited nearly 2 hrs they kept said doctor is busy 
I got very angry and I left the hospital. 

While I’m at hospital the nurses was rude and not really helpful at all, if u ask anything they just keep saying they are extremely busy, I had very bad experience all over the children A&E and children ward, this is not the first time and they can’t keep blaming covid sort of staff, I had very bad experience with other kids who was Admitted here 2021. 
Overall 0

title: Hands down the worst GP in London
body: It hasn’t been possible to get an appointment here since about 10 years ago. It’s a rat race for an “emergency appointment” you have to call at 8am on the dot to request a same day urgent appointment. That’s the only option you have. And they don’t even answer the phone. If they do answer, they’re always rude and dismissive. If you’re on hold until 8.05am, high chance there are no appointments left. You’re not allowed to discuss more than one issue at an appointment. Doctors aren’t there to listen to patients either. Extremely dismissive and frankly useless. The all read from the same script “what do you want me to do about it?” Followed by “we can’t offer you that” It’s a waste of time going in if you ever get an appointment. You’re better off going straight into a&e or self diagnosing online. Referrals are £25. And you have to pay for doctors notes. Every single time I have a health problem, I think of my gp and realise there’s no point looking for help so I let things get worse or escalate. This has been the case for as long as I can remember and I can’t help but feel like if I had a better GP a lot of health issues could have been avoided.

title: Terrible experience
body: Yesterday I went the hospital because of extreme pain on my left side of body. after 6 hours doctor told that I have kidney infection. I started to use antibiotics and pain relief which they gave me. But other day I had extraordinart pain and I was feeling like I have heart attack. I was crying with to much pain. Someone told me that they prepared pain killer but first I should see nurse. I waited one hour long in front of nurse door in a very very bad situation but they did not care. In this hospital staff does not care the patients and they are so slow while working. They don’t focus their job. I felt so unsecure. Because I was feeling so so bad because of extreme kidney and heart pain but they did not look at me.

readBy.name: Norfolk and Norwich University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: If it’s an emergency 111 are great
body: Phoned with an ongoing debilitating myalgia, fever and headache for 7 days over the Christmas period. Spoke to a call handler who booked me in 3 hours later. Great service. If you have a cold read the website.

readBy.name: Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Extremely poor practice
body: I did an online consultation for my 13 year old daughter, concerned that she might have an ear infection (as trying to get an appointment when you eventually get through on the phone is near impossible). I never received any communication at all from this surgery, which I find absolutely outrageous especially when it tells you someone will be in contact within 48 hours.

title: Really disappointed
body: So I went into the minor injury unit, as I am staying just up the road and it’s the nearest hospital. I suffer with chronic asthma and was suffering wit burning chest pains and wheezing. I was worrying I had pneumonia so I took my self down. There was only about 5 people in the waiting room but waiting two hours with bad breathing. I then got take in by what I assume is a triage nurse or something. I cannot explain how rude she was and made me feel so sad and uncomfortable. The second she came in she said take ur jacket off so I did and just put it in the bed. She then said in a rude manner why have you just done that that’s a clean sanitised bed whilst sighing at me clearly frustrated. I said I’m sorry I didn’t mean to and didn’t know. She then went on to say there was nothing wrong with me and I’m in the Same boat as everyone else as shouldn’t have come to a&e. I told her that I have been hospitalised numerous times with my asthma and it’s not a joke I have to get to a hospital asap or if it’s bad my lips turn blue. She made me feel like I didn’t matter at all. I didn’t feel like she looked after my properly and I felt very uncomfortable. So then the next nurse came in she was more polite but said she couldn’t hear a wheeze in my chest and said she was only goin to give me steroids and no antibiotics. They sent me home. And since I’ve been back I’ve deteriated massively my chest is wheezing louder than ever I can barely breath. I have suffered my whole life with asthma I know my condition and to be made to feel yesterday like there was nothing wrong me and they were making me feel like I was wasting their time. I’m not going to lie but pretty disgusted. Worst way I’ve ever been treated at a hospital. If I go in to any other a&e they rush me straight in because it’s asthma. But they really weren’t bothered about me. I won’t ever be recommending this place to anyone. I understand the nhs is struggling at the moment but you do not need to be rude to patients.

title: Poor communication
body: I arrived this morning at the poly clinic at 07:30 and waiting for the clinic to open there was no communication on the door alerting patients  there is no dr to prescribe medication. There was some really unwell patients waiting in the cold and it would have been helpful that this information was given to us so we could have made the decision to go home and call the hub but no we had to wait for your doors to open for us to get that information. Very poor and uncaring practice. Patients don’t want to come out in the cold maybe an idea would be that you should update your website with this important information for us as sick patients can try other means to get the help that we need.

readBy.name: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Good Practice
body:
My recent prostate PSA results came back really high
The Doctor immediately organised a second blood test and a flow test at Kettering Hospital I was most impressed 
Thankfully the second blood test came back satisfactory

title: Great practice
body: My experience was excellent. I didn’t have to wait and I had my flu jab with no pain or discomfort. The nurse was lovely , friendly and efficient.

title: Physio appointment
body: Saffron Walden community hospital is a lovely facility which I feel we’re lucky to access. The atmosphere is calm, quiet & spotlessly clean with friendly staff. However it’s very disturbing basic infection control mitigations seem to have been abandoned & mask wearing not encouraged in the same way Addenbrookes still does. So far with both my appointments the healthcare worker hasn’t worn a mask & even commented that I don’t need to either. All very well unless you have a vulnerable wife with chronic respiratory & blood clotting illness who as yet has managed to avoid Covid.

readBy.name: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fantastic care
body:
My daughter burnt her arm and the A&E team on New Year’s Day morning were so loving, caring, reassuring and professional. 
Thank you all for being so lovely.

readBy.name: Queen Victoria Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor discharge
body:
Whilst the hospital treatment and care was good, trying to be discharged was terrible.
Consultant was happy to let me go on the Friday subject physio and others. Was satisfied later in the day. Whilst seen by another doctor and physio the next day discharge did not happen. Sunday seen another doctor who was going to check what is going on.

Also, the noise some days, created by another patient, was not challenged. Hospital is not exactly a place for patients to watch netflix at what sounded like full volume

author: Grandpas
title: A terrible experience at Exeter RD & E
body:
At Exeter RD & E hospital, I had a terrible experience over a number of years of being fobbed off.  
Eventually made a complaint, long overdue. They didn't investigate the complaint properly, their letter of response was ridiculous with plenty of inaccurate points that I could prove were simply not true via paperwork in my possession. Only after I complained they came up with false allegations about me, defamatory in nature which I believe amounts to a form of victimisation, and which according to the hospital's own records, copies of which I have in my possession, are completely untrue.  
They did the usual NHS trick of passing it to the ombudsman. That is a waste of time because the ombudsman service only rarely finds for the complainant (just look at the statistics, out of 27885 complaints received 2021/2022 only 63 fully upheld (0.23%) and 307 (1.1%) partly upheld. I am still waiting for the ombudsman to come back to me with an outcome as they have only recently contacted me (when it was at least 9 months since I referred the matter to them).  
Due to the member of staff who made the untrue statements (who I reported to the HCPC), I can no longer attend that hospital at all since I have no witness to attend with me now, and I do not trust them to be honest or treat me properly. I believe that it is about time NHS staff were held personally accountable instead of hiding behind the NHS logo and blaming the system.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Blue Shoes
title: Patients should always come first
body:
I and my family have been patients at this surgery for a very long time. We feel this surgery has let us down and has gone downhill. They always maintain their patients come first, which we find so untrue.  
To get a appointment, that's if you are lucky, in a reasonable time is nearly impossible. When you phone you are left waiting for a age, then are given a list of options, which are not very helpful. When speaking to the receptionist about this they seem rude and abrupt with you, and when you question their system you are told to either book on a appointment on line or find another surgery in town which really shows they don't care.  
Then there is a issue when you put a complaint in that they don't appear to take it seriously and try to skip around it and take for ages to respond. It can months before you get any answers, which is not acceptable.  
We feel there is an arrogance the way this surgery conducts itself  
.Patients should always come first

author: Jamb22
title: My Dads stay in CICU
body:
My dad was transferred from Derby to Trent Cardiac Centre at the beginning of November. He had triple heart bypass surgery the day after admission and never woke up- we had to turn his life support off on the second day. Although he had had a mild heart attack 3 weeks prior he was otherwise fit and well. In general the staff were lovely, kind and patient.  
However I feel that he shouldn’t have died- I am a senior nurse myself and we have never received an adequate explanation of why he died!”? We’re his organs used (this was his wish), the anaesthetist in charge of his care on the 5th told my mum that her husband of 50+ years had bloods that were -incompatible with life-insensitive would be an understatement. I would like to have the opportunity to talk to those involved in my dads care as to why he died?

author: David Discontent
title: Access to rehab cross county
body:
My partner and I live in the village in Oxfordshire, however, the general practice is linked to Warwickshire. I wanted to bring the following to your attention not only because of the potential damage that has been done to my partner's long-term health but also the almost ludicrous financial implications of this for a cash strapped NHS.  
My partner had a stroke caused by a bleed on the brain at the beginning of December 2022. She was taken to the John Radcliffe acute stroke unit where she has been ever since. She was declared medically fit to move to rehab 4 days later. The John Radcliffe managed to arrange for her to have a bed at the Leamington Spa Rehab Hospital.  
The problem has then arisen because University Hospital Coventry have intervened and have said that she cannot enter rehab until she has been assessed at the hospital in Coventry, despite having the JR assessments. It is only after this that she can be moved to Leamington. Since then numerous contacts have been made by the John Radcliffe to Coventry and in addition I have made calls myself. The response has been that they will not make a bed available because they are not accepting any cross county transfers. They are unable to advise when this might change and therefore she remains in limbo.  
As you appreciate the recovery from a stroke is largely dependent on the sort of rehab that you receive early on. As she has been blocked from receiving this care by, for how long who knows , she is unable to move forward. My partner is in her early 60s she is very fit and fortunately her cognition is largely undamaged. She is also a very determined goals based person that would benefit enormously from the right sort of care. As you can see from the above this treatment of her by the Warwickshire Health Authority is difficult to comprehend on any level. Aside from a number of NHS protocols that are being broken treatment wise. There is also the wider implications of having an acute bed blocked at the John Radcliffe at whatever that might cost per day. An unnecessary ambulance journey, an acute bed blocked Coventry hospital and the resulting delays in the treatment she needs urgently.  
My partner as I have said is by nature a strong determined woman but this lack of progress is severely damaging her mental well-being. She has moved from having a positive attitude into a very dark place. This too cannot be an acceptable way of treating someone who has already had a life disruption of this nature.  
I hope you don’t mind me contacting via this medium but I thought you should be aware of what appears to be an inflexible attitude and also because as you will appreciate I am very concerned about my partners future, both medical and mentally, if this impasse continues.  
I look forward to hearing from you.

author: AliC
title: GP and misinformation
body:
I was an inpatient at Wishaw General. On the day I was discharged I was told they had taken a biopsy, 2 weeks later as I still hadn't received any news of the results and was in pain, I called my GP surgery to ask for pain relief and if they knew the outcome of the biopsy.  
When I was discharged I was given cocodamol 30/500, but my GP would only prescribe 30/500 and told me if I was in enough pain that they didn't help I should go to Wishaw again. I explained to my GP how anxious I was and that it being Christmas and new year, I can't relax to enjoy it with my children waiting on these results. My GP informed me there was no biopsy done, they were reading a very in-depth letter from the gynaecology dept and there's no mention of a biopsy being done.  
Today I received a letter with an appt to go discuss the results of my recent biopsy. I called to complain to the GP practice and was told by office staff that yes they could in fact see that they were noted about the biopsy and that the hospital have said on the letter that they will contact me direct with results and a copy of the letter will be sent to my GP.  
I said I'd like to complain as the GP told me I was worrying over nothing and no biopsy had ever been taken. They advised me that even though they'd seen it on the letter, it was in the small print and the GP had maybe missed it.  
I'm horrified tbh. I understand that mistakes can happen and the hospital have contacted me anyway, but they actually made me feel like I was going mad and worrying over nothing. Turns out I most likely haven't been, as they want me in to discuss the results and haven't given them over the phone.

author: jadeh
title: Poor aftercare, no duty of care
body:
My 82-year-old Grandma was placed here to recover from an operation for a new hip following a fall in her garden. She has had several falls over the past 12 months and is very unsteady on her feet. She also has regular infections which have led to sepsis 8 times.  
Whilst on the Oakham Ward at this hospital she has been very unwell, has not received physio as promised, and is now being released home. My mum has been on the phone daily to try and ensure she is placed in a care home for a small amount of time to allow her to recover and hopefully regain some of her mobility to allow her to go back home.  
She was told that she had a place at a local care home, only for that to be cancelled and told they're sending her home with 2 carers a day. That is 23 hours a day she will be left alone, with the nearest family member a 40-minute drive away. She is unable to dress herself, cook for herself, take herself to the bathroom or complete any normal day-to-day tasks.  
The duty of care provided has been horrific, this is an accident waiting to happen. She has worked her entire life, paid into the system, and all the hospital are interested in is getting rid of her to free space for another patient to come in. The lack of understanding and remorse has been horrific, and when an accident does happen and she is seriously injured or worse, no one will be there to take liability.  
It may be nothing to the healthcare workers, but she is everything to us - the NHS need to sort their priorities out and improve care for those who have contributed for their entire existence. Disgusting.

author: catherine05
title: Unfair treatment
body:
I have been under the care of The Track Team at Udston Hospital for many years now, as I have Primary Progressive 1 MS they are now named stroke/neurological team.  
Moira mentioned Botox injections to improve the spasticity in my right leg, which has worsened. Therefore, I contacted Moira suggesting it was possibly time to try the injection, to learn she is now only allowed to perform such activity on stroke patients and she would have to refer me to Glasgow.  
This is quite an inconvenience, given I live in the same area as Udston Hospital, where Moira is based. I struggle with public transport, and find it very unfair that I am already a patient of Moira, who is trained to treat me with botox injections. Yet since their name has changed, Moira is not allowed to administer the injections to MS patients, only Stroke patients.  
I honestly don’t understand the logic in that given both illnesses are neurological issues, why can’t I have the treatment I need at the clinic I am already attending??? As I would be treated much quicker.

author: Ad99mson
title: Patient Care
body:
Delighted to hear about what your staff members were doing out with of their shift, instead of actually seeing to patients that had been waiting for over 2 hours.  
My wife was basically told she was a liar, even though the information she was providing was previously provided to from a midwife. I couldn’t get the nurse's name, as no badge was present nor a name provided.  
Night shift or not and busy or not, staff should not take their attitude out of anyone, absolutely appalled.

author: echoxn36
title: I felt so belittled and patronised
body:
My experience at Wishaw Maternity was mercifully short. I am 9 weeks pregnant, my third pregnancy past 6 weeks, and like to think I kind of know what I'm doing and what's normal.  
Obviously, the nausea and sickness is also normal. However, I suddenly experienced 24 hours of constant vomiting and fainting, not even water would stay down, and I was admitted to the Monklands Hospital, who were very quick to realise I was severely dehydrated and put me on anti-sickness and fluids.  
I couldn't even walk without feeling like I would faint again. During one of these fainting episodes, I broke my nose on tiles. At 5pm the Monklands staff contacted Wishaw to transfer me to a more suitable ward with experience in dehydration in pregnancy and we could hopefully check if the baby was OK and in the right place, as they were concerned it was an ectopic pregnancy.  
Wishaw agreed to transfer, so we drove 30 mins over. We waited 3 hours in the waiting room, everything was spinning. At this point I hadn't eaten or drank anything in roughly 24 hours.  
Eventually, I went to the midwives' desk and asked how much longer it would take, and they actually asked me why I was there. I was very confused, as the Wishaw team were the ones that confirmed the transfer and would organise more fluids etc. I gave them my name and the midwife at the front actually looked at me and told me that being sick is actually a sign of a healthy pregnancy.  
I've never felt so patronised, it was the worst thing they could have said to me after 24 hours of hell. They wanted me to explain what I expected them to do. I asked if they read my notes, they said yes and yet they still wanted me to explain why I was there. I told them to take the IV thing out of my arm because I wouldn't be staying, I don't care if I pass out again I just wanted to go home.  
I don't know why they allowed us to wait for 3 hours. I don't know why they authorised the transfer if they didn't plan on doing anything. Thankfully, I'm feeling better with the anti-sickness medication.  
I've never abused hospital services, especially with nausea, but I felt so belittled and patronised in that moment that it put me off ever going to Wishaw even if my leg is hanging off.

author: Darcy Buttercup
title: Ward doors and patient safety
body:
On visiting Ward 35 for the elderly, I found the door ajar. I closed it and shortly afterwards a nurse opened it and walked off. I challenged her and she said she was sorry.  
I then completed a visit to my relative. On leaving the door was ajar again. I closed it. Then a nurse opened and left it open. Another asked me to keep it open to let her in. I observed from the stairwell and this kept happening over a few mins. I went back to the nursing station and a junior nurse told me the staff nurse said it’s left open to stop people buzzing.  
The other nurse walked with me to close it and agreed it should be closed due to the wandering nature of some patients.  
For a geriatric ward on the 4th floor of the hospital, beside large concrete staircases, I don’t feel nurses are putting patient safety over a simple process of either buzzing in, or having a code to enter. There’s good reason for securing the door and it shouldn’t be left open just because the junior nurse might have to check and let someone in.  
If my mother escapes and falls I will hold the staff nurse for ward 25 responsible and NHS for this area accountable.

author: Effed Off
title: Waiting for hours with a three-year-old
body:
Sat in Larbert hospital at the moment. Been sat waiting for 8 hours and still haven't been seen.  
This is for a 3 year old with extremely high temperatures and with all the symptoms of Strep A and no one seems interested.  
There's no order to the people being seen.

author: Jackwabbit56
title: Long delays in being seen and admitted
body:
My wife has had to be taken to Darent Valley hospital 3 times in the last 3 months, with severe breathing problems. Our experience on all 3 occasions is the hospital needs to be a lot larger, and with a lot more staff to deal with the volumes of patients going or being sent there by the 111 service or GPs.  
1st visit, sent by 111 service. Triage took about an hour to be seen and it took 8 hours waiting to see a doctor, only to be told she needed an x-ray (could this not have been decided at the time of triage?). Another 2 hours after the x-ray was spent sitting in the main waiting area to see the doctor again to tell her she has pneumonia and fluid on her lung. A total of 27 hours in A&E before a bed was found.  
2 weeks were spent on Palm ward, staff very good but obviously rushed off their feet. 1 week Hospital at Home care, again the staff that came out were very good. This was followed by 2 visits to the Ambulatory care, where she was discharged on the 2nd visit, despite having a lot of chest pain and still having fluid on the lung.  
2 weeks later, 2nd visit to A&E with the same problem. Once again 7 to 8 hours waiting to see a doctor and another 27 hours before a bed could be found. Once again the nursing staff were very good but some of the doctors could be a lot better! One came to my wife & said: "have you had cancer before?" When my wife said, "No, have I got it now?" his reply was "I can't discuss this now until you have a close member of your family with you."  
Once again she was discharged from the ward to the Ambulatory care who saw her one evening in December a couple of days later before discharging her, still with fluid on the lung and spreading into the abdomen.  
Late December, she was taken by ambulance to DVH A&E at 08:30 where bloods and x-rays were done by 09:30. By 12:30 ambulance crews were being told to take new patients back out to the ambulances to hold awaiting space in A&E. Staff were tripping over equipment, each other and patients just trying to treat people. As I have already said most of the staff were very good, but working under immense pressure.  
There have been thousands of new homes built in Dartford alone, let alone all the other development in the South East since this hospital was built. It just cannot cope with the volumes it is getting at the moment.

author: Sanderal
title: DXA scan, great care - brilliant service!
body: Karl & Ben very personable and professional. Explained procedure and carried it out with great care - brilliant service!

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Helhs58
title: This situation really requires to be addressed.
body:
Took my husband into A&E this morning, was taken fairly quick and was told he was to be admitted, he waited 14 hours sitting on a chair before they could give him a bed.  
The staff were 1st class and doing their best but this situation really requires to be addressed.

title: Safe in good hands
body: Had a 5 day stay in glenfield hospital visiting the emergency day center , cdu then ward  23a. I cannot fault the professionalism, thoroughness and care from the staff .

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: Excellent Service
body: Offered a respiratory clinic spot in lieu of GP appt. Appt was with respiratory specialist doctor. Only a few minutes waiting in reception and thorough examination by doctor who made prescription out online for immediate dispensing at local chemist. Prescription ready when arrived.

author: Ontheotherside
title: I went home feeling so much better after a small procedure!
body:
I was seen by gp/gmeds for the 3rd time in 3 week’s following swallowing issues and suspected tonsillitis.  
I was then referred to Ear Nose Throat (ENT) today and the staff were amazing. They went above and beyond to ensure I was well looked after - especially on such a busy day of the year and a day I am sure they would rather have spent with their families.  
Nothing was a bother and I went home feeling so much better after a small procedure!

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

title: Very professional practice
body: End of last year i had a wrist opporation and chose to have a block instead of a general anaesthetic. After i had been given a full unhurried explanation of what a block entailed by the anethatist, and given ample time to think about it. My decision was based on the confidence i felt in their professional ability and trust in their enthusiasm and competencey in this proceedure,  I would highly recommende it. It was a positive experience and i felt very looked after. Also not to have the side effects from a general anaesthetic after was a big bonus.

readBy.name: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great care
body:
I would like to pass on my thanks to all the staff on mandarin A ward who cared for my father during the time he spent on the ward. He was treated with great care and compassion and respect.  The care was also extended to me and my family and when he unfortunately passed away the staff could not have been kinder.  I hope this is passed on to them all
 They are Angels.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Excellent
body: I’m writing here from the perspective of a person that in work has to deal with most surgeries in the are. I find Yorkshire Street Surgery to be one of the best. Yea there are things that I would ideally change but they are issues common to all practices and because of the pressures they are under. When the issue have needed to be dealt with fast they have been and reasonably timed appointments have been available for things that can wait a bit. Follow up tests and results have been completed without delay. Thank you for your work as this can’t be easy.

title: Excellent service
body: We were away in Southport when my baby became unwell. I took her to the walk in clinic and was pleasantly surprised by the short wait time and the pleasant staff that we met. The receptionist was friendly, the health care assistant assessed my baby within minutes of being there and then after about an hours wait we saw a lovely doctor. He was very thorough and excellent with my baby. Thank you to all there for all you do. An excellent service.

title: Effective practice
body:
Using NHS 111, I found that the UTC was telephone only rather than walk-in, which I thought would be a problem but was actually very useful. I sent in my details and received a call from a doctor within 1 and a half hours, bearing in mind this was in the evening, just before closing time, on New Year's Eve (so one of the busiest days of the year). 

The doctor was very helpful, exceptionally clear in explaining all the possibilities of what my condition could be and provided some good advice options. Overall I am pleased with the service, but I'm glad I checked online beforehand about the telephone service only.

author: Foot injury
title: Great advice and time over the phone
body:
I would like to thank the charge nurse on shift. I recently had a very bad sprained wrist and I called for advice.  
Despite the time of the year and what I can imagine a very busy time for the NHS, she was so kind. She gave me great advice and time over the phone, thank you so much.

title: Amazing staff in the Children’s emergency…
body: I had to take my daughter to the children’s emergency department this evening . I can not thank them enough for the level of care and compassion shown . The consultant and nurse who saw my daughter were truly amazing they were so kind , caring and compassionate took the time to speak with her , throughly assessing her and given a swift diagnosis. The consultant we saw appeared to be South African and explained he had come in today at short notice due to his colleague being unwell . He was so kind and reassuring whilst doing all his assessment and medical checks . He really does show how amazing the people are who work for our NHS that’s why we should be proud and respectful to our service and its staff .

title: Excellent paediatric emergency department
body: Reception check in was satisfactory and then in paediatric A&E the staff were so caring, kind, focussed and knowledgeable. I felt that my son was safe and would be made well again. We were seen promptly and in the right order of severity of symptoms. Couldn’t fault anyone.

title: Emergency help
body: I was in pain due to a urinary infection and the 2 members of reception staff I spoke to were very kind and helpful. I successfully was referred to a doctor and got a prescription.

title: Great hospital
body: Had a procedure done here. The staff were amazing, nothing too much trouble, anaesthetist was very informative and put me at ease. In and out quickly and the hospital was very clean.

title: Speedy service and treatment
body: We went today and the WIC was so quiet we were triaged, treat d and given a prescription within half an hour. Staff from receptionist to the nurses were all lovely and made my daughter very relaxed

title: Speedy service and treatment
body: We went today and the WIC was so quiet we were triaged, treat d and given a prescription within half an hour. Staff from receptionist to the nurses were all lovely and made my daughter very relaxed

author: Sweenatrow3
title: You all do an amazing job and I'm so thankful to you all
body:
I recently had a baby and wanted to express how amazing all the staff were.  
From my amazing community midwife who was there from start to finish, always helpful, supportive and approachable. To triage who were so kind and reassuring when we had concerns and struggling with a prolonged labour. To labour ward and my midwife Charlotte who listened to what was important to me and made me feel involved in my care and stayed with us until the end.  
The theatre staff who were so friendly and explained everything so well when things didn't go to plan, the recovery staff who were friendly, kind and helpful after theatre.  
A huge thank you to the staff on summerfield ward they were great especially the Healthcare assistants who took so much time to help me with my struggle to breastfeed,I couldn't have managed without their help and advice.  
You all do an amazing job and I'm so thankful to you all.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: elephanttx73
title: I still got the same problem
body: I went for test results, was negative but I still got the same problem. I don't understand. Now I have to go for test again,

title: Extremely kind
body: My father spent a few days on the gastro ward before he was moved to hospice care. Every member of staff was kind,informative and easy to talk to.

title: Very good experience
body: I used e-consult and the GP called me the same day and, following a discussion, an appointment was arranged for the next day. The appointment was on time, very thorough and the GP organised prescriptions and an X-ray. All were promptly completed despite this happening between Xmas and New Year. I was worried that there might be long delays because of the holiday period etc, but not so. I was very impressed. Thank you Longrove and NHS.

title: Very good service
body: I attended for a walk in X-ray between Xmas and New Year. I was expecting a long wait, but was seen promptly and treated kindly and courteously from reception onwards. What a great service. Press reports etc made me worried in advance, so I am writing this to recognise the excellent service and to reassure others.

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

title: Dr Adebanjo
body:
A while back I called to ask for a doctor to call out to see my elderly mum as she was very poorly.
Dr Adebanjo called out to see her. He was a breath of fresh air the minute he entered my mums.
He was professional and very thorough, he was caring he listened and let us explain what the issue was and he then went through all her medication gave her a full examination I cannot praise this doctor enough! He is a Credit to The Valley medical centre. He reassured myself and mum and got to the bottom of her problem. I cannot thank him enough! Thank you so much for your help and support.

author: Chagger
title: Unsung heroes
body:
My father presented with symptoms of a stroke and 2 paramedics arrived from East of England ambulance trust. I think their names were Ben and Georgia (or something very similar).  
They were professional, courteous, reassuring, slick and very helpful a credit to their profession. Unsung heroes. Please pass on my thanks

title: Excellent Service and Support
body:
On 23rd December, I took my daughter to the children’s a&e department. She had burnt her hand on our gas stove while helping to cook dinner. 

As soon as we come into the department we were helped straight away, water therapy was given and lots of care and attention. 

We attended the department two more times over the course of the week for redressing. There was a lovely nurse who helped us both times and was fantastic with my daughter. 

I know I can’t say any names of the nurses who helped, but everyone who helped us each time, was polite, friendly and so caring. They all went above and beyond to help and am so grateful for the care my daughter received. 

There’s a nurse in particular we see twice, she was just lovely! Caring and kind and excellent at bandaging! 

Thank you so much, I hope this review reaches the kind nurses that helped. As all too often we see negative comments. 

Would highly recommend this department! 
Happy new year!

title: Caring Practice
body: My wife who suffers dementia,took a nasty fall on Thursday 26/12/22.The Hillingdon Health Centre Practice Manager,was superb in securing a vital assessment visit by the community matron/nurse with inside 4 hours,as they were aware of my wife's vulnerabilities.Fantastic caring work of which I thank you.

title: Kind and compassionate
body: Everyone at Warwick Park was kind, compassionate and caring towards my mum in the last few weeks of her life. They were friendly and courteous and I knew she was in good hands

author: Chagger
title: Slick, personalised, kind and highly professional process.
body:
My elderly father was admitted with a suspected stroke.  
He was triaged speedily and professionally by the nursing team (one of whom was called Maurice) and then seen immediately by a very professional and compassionate A and E registrar called Fiona.  
Fiona rapidly transferred his care to the stroke team (stroke nurse Fidelma and registrar Dr Ngwako) who ensured that the process through was slick, personalised, kind and highly professional. He had a C T scan within 60 mins of arrival and a diagnosis shortly afterwards.  
Despite the hospital having all its beds occupied they managed to find a bed in the A and E Department so he could sleep.  
This hospital has the Regional Stroke unit. You can see why from entering the department right through his care was exemplary.  
Well done Northwick Park hospital A and E and Stroke teams and thank you.  
Please pass on my thanks to all involved

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Great Welcome
body:
Greeted on arrival, everyone very friendly, put at ease straight away. Everything explained,  a fantastic experience ! 
After the operation, the procedure for the eye drops explained.
Any worries were for nothing !

title: shoulder replacement
body:
After having had cancer (Hodgkins lymphoma) as a young man I was left with very high anxiety levels regarding anything that involved doctors or hospitals. On the day of my surgery for a total shoulder replacement I was beyond myself with all I can describe as 'fear'. All levels of staff at Pontefract Hospital were fantastic at helping reduce my very high anxiety levels in particular the anesthesiologist who was a very empathetic and extremely understanding young man I can honestly say I don't think I would have coped without the caring understanding nature of this chap. 
Overall I am very happy with the treatment I received and am now on the road to recovery, everyone involved throughout my procedure and aftercare have been second to none.

title: Excellent triage service
body: The system of calling to be triaged worked very well. The staff member I spoke to was professional, compassionate and listened and repeated what I said to ensure clarity. I was clear on what the next steps were and I was called back the next morning to arrange an appointment. During the appointment I was reassured that I have made the right choice to ask for an appointment (I was concerned that the surgery was very busy with people worse off than myself). I was very happy with the treatment I received for myself and my daughter. We were able to get medication straight after the appointment. All in all the service was efficient, professional and my concerns were taken seriously and we were treated very well indeed. The service was an excellent experience and much easier than making an appointment in the past. The triage system works very well.

title: Great service
body: I called at 8am and got an appointment the same day. The service was very professional and caring. I would recommend this practice to anyone.

title: Reassuring
body: I had cataract surgery & was extremely nervous. However, the staff in the Opthalmology department were brilliant. From the nurses to the anaesthetist to the surgeon. All were friendly, explained everything & answered any questions I had. I had my procedure done early & so no hanging around & I was made a lovely cup of tea afterwards. I felt it was a very positive & reassuring experience.

readBy.name: The Dudley Group NHS Foundation Trust

title: Helpful and Supportive Practice
body: We had a great experience getting help for my little one. The receptionist was able to find us an appointment and when we saw the GP, he was incredibly thorough and provided an accurate diagnosis. Really friendly team at Lonsdale. Thank you so much.

title: Guardian Angels
body: On 31st December I got admitted to King's Lynm hospital with acute pelvic pain. I was on my own, upset and scared. From speaking the 111 call taker to the end of my visit on Sandringham Ward, I was extremely well looked after. I want to give a very special mention to the nurses, doctors and porters in A&E, SAU and especially the Sandringham Ward for being absolutely amazing with me, giving me the highest standard of care. They doctors, nurses and porters need to be recognised as they are guardian angels in disguise to me. They worked tirelessly to ensure that I was comfortable, well looked after and they reassured me the whole time I was there. At not one point during my stay did I feel uncomfortable in that hospital, despite the whole hospital being under immense pressure. They deserve so much more! Thank you for looking after me.

author: PaulPrasad
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: His kindness will never be forgotten
body:
A very quick and sincere email .....and apologies its taken so long to write.  
Paul looked after my father in his final days in May 2022. I can only apologise for the delay its taken to send an email to thank Paul and McMillan team for all of their help during my father’s last few days.  
Paul exemplifies all the qualities needed to deal with such illness and his help, knowledge, empathy and sincere willingness to appease all was truly appreciated by myself, my mother and extended family. It’s hard to put into words how Paul helped ease the pain and my father truly felt at ease knowing Paul was there to help as he slipped away.  
My guilt is that my message of appreciation has taken so long to post...however his kindness will never be forgotten.  
I’d really appreciate if this message was passed to Paul.  
If possible , please wish Paul and team all the very best wishes over the Christmas Period and a Happy, Healthy and Peaceful New Year

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: PatientUK
title: Makes young patients reluctant to go to a doctor.
body:
I'm a male aged mid 20s. I've had issues with my stomach area for 2-3 years. I did get an endoscopy done around a year ago. It said I had multiple areas of extrinsic compressions. I still don't know what's causing these, nor do I know why I'm still in pain. I was told that it's IBS.  
Other than the endoscopy, I've never had a face to face appointment. I went to my GP a couple of months back as I've lost 3/4 of a stone in weight. My GP requested an urgent colonoscopy but the Doctor who did the phone appointments wrote to the GP saying that it's not required and to see a dietician. I'm a graduate - I had the sense to adjust my diet first before I sought medical advice.  
It's this kind of experience that makes young patients reluctant to go to a doctor.

author: runningxy64
title: Outstanding compassionate care
body:
My mother was a patient in Ramone 1 for 10 days.  
The nursing was exceptional - I cannot speak highly enough of the nurses, Health Care Assistants and the support service staff who align their core values with the those of the Trust.  
A special mention to nurses Aoife and Emma who delivered outstanding compassionate care to my mother.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Outstanding service
body:
I felt compelled to write something about the level of care I have received today. The staff on the Emergency Floor have been outstanding. They work under extreme pressure and still think about the patient first.

Well done to everyone involved and thank you

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Withgratitude
title: There is so much to say thank you for
body:
We cannot speak too highly of the service provided particularly by Vikki, and the others in the team, including too the Falls Nurse Vicky.  
From the patient: It has made the house much more liveable in for me. It is so much easier to use our difficult staircase. There is now an additional hand rail to the banister on the stairs and a made-to-measure grab rail on the awkward bend. The shower is much more usable with a seat and convenient well-sited grab handle. and the walkers upstairs and down make moving around so much easier. Everyone has been so friendly and helpful, listened to my needs and acted very promptly. Thank you for an excellent service. From the partner/carer: For me, the help received was a life-saver. After my husband became unwell, I was amazed at how quickly we were contacted and received help, giving us not only the help already mentioned but also the reassurance and advice so vitally needed at such a time. Thanks to Vikki, not only do we have extremely helpful aids in place but have had help with physiotherapy and advice as to where to go to fill in forms (such as much appreciated experienced help with filling in the attendance allowance form) and where to get additional help if needed including the important red alarm button! The visit and subsequent help from the falls nurse, Vicky was also greatly appreciated. There is so much to say thank you for. We are both immensely grateful.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: CaroHannah
title: You don’t get many like her!
body:
Sabrina visited me before I had my second child, and I have to say from the get go she has been fantastic. A normal health visitor who understands what it’s like being a new mum, she doesn’t talk at you or down to you, she just has a lovely way with people and babies!  
She is extremely knowledgeable about all things baby and even though this is my second child I actually learnt so much from her.  
I will actually miss Sabrina coming to see us. You don’t get many like her!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: greencs67
title: Wonderful care
body:
I attended The Victoria infirmary yesterday. I was there from 8am until 4pm,  
Siobhan Smith was the Nurse that looked after me I can not fault anything she done in that time not only for me but for other patients too .

author: statuspm68
title: Complete confidence in the clinical support and referrals
body:
My wife has suffered from a Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) for many years but most recently for over 3 weeks without resolution despite good care from the GP practice.  
Having been referred to Hospital@Home, Dr Watt and Fiona have been very attentive and supportive. My wife has complete confidence in the clinical support and referrals to seek to find a lasting solution.  
Thanks to all involved including the labs and we know how much pressure everyone is under.

readBy.name: South Ayrshire Health and Social Care Partnership

title: No Mask wearing
body: When Flu and Covid cases are rising why oh why are no patients waiting for their blood test being asked to wear a mask. The brilliant Plebotomy staff wear masks! As someone that is immunosuppressed I can't believe the coughing and sneezing in the waiting area. Surely someone should taking decisive action please.

title: Excellent care
body: I was taken by ambulance following a consultation with my GP to KGH on 13 December 2022. From the moment I arrived I cannot speak highly enough of the first class treatment I received from all grades of staff, even though they were under tremendous pressure. Following blood tests and chest X-ray and being hooked up to oxygen, I was informed that I would be admitted to hospital. Due to shortage of beds I stayed in A&E for 24 hours, then transferred to Clifford Ward, then eventually arrived on Harrowden C Ward.  Once again I must commend the staff on these wards for the first class care I received.  I would also like to mention hospital food.  One hears so many bad comments about this subject, but I must say that the menu offered was extensive and something to suit everybody's taste, varied with copious portions.  I can fully recommend the Omelettes, so thank you Chef! In my opinion restaurant quality.

readBy.name: Kettering General Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appointment
body: I like most people cannot get a appointment either. Not even a phone call. I ring every day to be told no there is no appointments. How am I supposed to get my illness sorted and treated. 10 minutes with a doctor is all I need . Getting a appointment used to be easy. So what as happened. I've been suffering for a while now please sort the appointments out

title: Great practice.
body: My experience with my Dr from start to ongoing has been excellent care. Unfortunately getting the appointment in the first instant was was very difficult
